title.narrative: Study on Masculinity and Gender Norms in Liberia

description.narrative: During the two civil wars of Liberia (1989-2003), rape and other forms of sexual abuse were a widespread weapon of war. Liberia has now been peaceful for 15 years, but sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) remains rampant. There is limited analysis available on the root causes of the high prevalence of SGBV cases, rape especially. The Embassy of Sweden has therefore identified the need for a masculinity study which will study the interlinks between gender norms, masculinity, patriarchal norms and SGBV. A key objective with this study is to develop theories of change and development interventions that begin challenging negative notions of masculinity, which can be used by the Embassy and other development partners in Liberia.

Under Liberias två inbördeskrig (1989-2003) användes våldtäkt och andra former av sexuellt våld som ett vapen i konflikterna. Liberia har nu varit fredligt i 15 år, men sexuellt och könsbaserat våld fortsätter att vara utbrett. Det finns begränsad analys tillgänglig om de grundläggande orsakerna till den höga förekomsten av könsbaserat och sexuellt våld. Den svenska ambassaden har därför identifierat behovet av en maskulinitetsstudie som ska undersöka sambanden mellan könsnormer, maskulinitet, patriarkala normer och könsbaserat och sexuellt våld. Ett huvudsyfte med denna studie är att utveckla förändringteorier som börjar utmana negativa uppfattningar om maskulinitet, som kan användas av ambassaden och andra utvecklingspartner i Liberia.

This intervention was designed for the undertaking of a study on norms of masculinities in Liberia. The objectives included; (1) exploring how gender norms and masculinity in Liberia are constructed, what forms they take and what effects they have on women, girls, boys and men, and society at large. (2) Exploring specifically how norms of masculinity impact SGBV. (3) Exploring positive social norms and positive aspects of masculinity that can present opportunities to involve men in ending VAW/G.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The outcome of the intervention was very satisfactory, and the research questions were answered within the scope of a study of this size and focus. The study concluded that hegemonic masculinity is the dominant form of masculinity which includes associating being “masculine,” with physical strength, providing protection, taking on the role of breadwinner, making decisions, hiding emotions, and being dominant, whereas being “feminine” is conflated with submissiveness, taking care of the family and domestic duties, with limitations on her mobility, appearance and behavior. None of outcomes were particularly surprising but aligns with previous research in the field. Despite this, ‘The challenge of unlearning’ manages to stay relevant. The study highlighted areas for further research, including the impact of these norms on children, perceptions of LGBT+, and positive masculinities. This study contributes to the baseline on gender and social norms in Liberia and will contribute as part of a foundation for further programming, both by the Swedish Embassy and by development partners.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
